properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected. An intense weather system will generate strong southeast winds across the north and central coasts and Haida Gwaii today, as well as northern Vancouver Island this evening. The southeast winds will peak at speeds of 80 to 100 km/h across Haida Gwaii this afternoon followed by the north and central coasts, and northern Vancouver Island this evening. After the system passes through, the southeast winds will shift to west winds with gusts up to 70 km/h overnight and then rise to westerly 90 km over most of Haida Gwaii and the North Coast on Thursday morning. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T10:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T19:00:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1657140635.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. What: Snow, heavy at times. An additional 2 to 4 cm of snow is expected this evening. Where: Greater Sudbury, North Bay, and Killarney. This includes sections of the following highways: - Highway 17 - Highway 69 - Highway 11 - Highway 6 When: Until late this evening. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: An Alberta Clipper will track across central Ontario this evening bringing heavy snow and total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact travel. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T03:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T20:41:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1756284341.2021
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Espanola - Killarney

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values between minus 50 and minus 55 will develop by Thursday morning. Wind chills near minus 50 have already developed along the north coast of the Northwest Territories. This cold air will move southward overnight. These extreme cold wind chill values will persist into Friday and may linger into the weekend in some communities. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T14:29:03-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing low pressure system is set to affect the southern Kivalliq beginning on Thursday. As the low approaches, light snow and strong southerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h will begin in Arviat, Rankin Inlet and Chesterfield Inlet on Thursday morning. This is expected to bring blowing snow with poor visibility lasting for a few hours. The winds will then switch to the northwest and are expected to bring blizzard conditions with near zero visibility lasting until Friday morning. In Baker Lake, winds are expected to rapidly increase to 50 km/h gusting to 70 on Thursday morning from the northwest. This combined with light snow will create blizzard conditions with poor visibility lasting until Friday morning. This low will continue to push East and create further blowing snow events for Coral Harbour and Kinngait on Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T08:21:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T16:22:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2326278419.2021
Area: Baker Lake, Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, at times heavy, bringing total amounts of 10 to 15 cm Thursday. Heavy snow will begin early Thursday morning bringing 10 cm of new snow by the evening. Snowfall will taper off overnight with an additional 5 cm of snow possible by Friday morning. Gusty north winds after the snowfall may result in local blowing snow in exposed areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds, gusting up to 100 km/h will develop late this evening. The strongest wind gusts will be in wind prone areas and will persist through the day on Thursday before easing on Thursday night. In Banff and Jasper National Parks, including the Icefields Parkway, snow will accompany these strong winds resulting in locally poor visibility in blowing snow. Blowing snow may also impact sections of Highway 11 west of Nordegg. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T14:27:19-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Temperatures near minus 40 combined with northwesterly winds of 15 km/h will bring extreme wind chill values of minus 55 and colder to Sanirajak and Igloolik overnight. These extreme cold wind chill values will linger through Thursday and Thursday night, before slightly improving Friday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with visibility below 400 m will continue. Strong winds are likely reducing visibility in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will persist until winds ease early this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A developing low pressure system will bring blizzard conditions to the southern Kivalliq on Thursday. Light snow and southerly winds gusting up to 70 km/h will begin in Arviat, Rankin Inlet, and Chesterfield Inlet early Thursday morning. This will bring blowing snow with poor visibilities for a few hours. In the afternoon, winds will shift to the northwest and are expected to bring blizzard conditions with near zero visibility lasting until Friday morning. In Baker Lake, on Thursday morning, northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h will develop, bringing blizzard conditions with near zero visibility to the community. These blizzard conditions will gradually improve Friday evening. Thursday evening, along with the blizzard conditions, temperatures will drop to minus 40 and lower in the southern Kivalliq. These frigid temperatures combined with the gusty northwest winds will give extreme wind chill values of minus 60 to minus 65. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T12:35:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T20:36:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3410165515.2021

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A ridge of high pressure over NWT combined with a low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska will generate strong easterly winds near the Richardson Mountains late today into Thursday. These winds will give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. What: Snow, heavy at times. An additional 2 to 4 cm of snow is expected this evening. Where: Regions along the northeastern shore of Georgian Bay east through Algonquin to the Ottawa River. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 69 -Highway 400 -Highway 11 -Highway 17 When: Snow will continue until late this evening. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: An Alberta Clipper will track across central Ontario this evening bringing heavy snow and total accumulations of 10 to 15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions and impact travel. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T09:59:07-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. An approaching frontal system will move inland tonight and across the B.C. interior on Thursday. Snow will begin overnight tonight and persist through Thursday. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm can be expected by Thursday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-25T14:59:59-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A period of heavy snow is forecast tonight as a Pacific frontal system moves cross the central interior. The snow will ease to a few flurries by overnight or Thursday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
